scenes.location: GUASPARI HOUSEHOLD, ROME, N. Y. BEDROOM
characters: HOPES RUN HIGH BEAUTIFUL MUSICIAN WILL CALL FOR A DATE
CREDITS OVER PHOTOS IN AN ALBUM

dialogues.speaker: CREDITS OVER PHOTOS IN AN ALBUM
dialogues.text: The photos include a sepia-tone portrait of an Italian  immigrant family... a b&w snapshot of ROBERTA, a nine old girl playing violin in front of a refrigerator (1950) ...Roberta and her dashing Italian father, hand-carving a wooden music stand... a b&w snapshot of Roberta in a dress... Roberta at 15, playing violin in front of the sa refrigerator, eyes on the music stand... ...a color photo of two cute blonde little boys building sandcastle on a beach... a color photo of a groom in a wh naval uniform and his pretty bride, (Roberta at 25), her  hand over his as they cut their wedding cake with a sword ...a color photo of Roberta and her husband Greek dancing with another couple at an outdoor taverna. Roberta's husb and the other man's sexy wife are exchanging a slight smi HOLD ON THIS LAST PHOTO as we now see the ALBUM open on t floor of a bedroom, as if it's been tossed. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, Roberta!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the sound of KNOCKING as the CAMERA PANS a small, darkened guest room. A few streaks of daylight filter thr Venetian blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Bert -- get out of bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA finds a WOMAN lying face down on a twin bed, t wavy hair sprawled across her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Bert -- you need to get out  of that bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KNOCKING continues, and she puts the pillow over the of her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOMAN -- ROBERTA GUASPARI-DEMETRAS (38) -- retrieves photo album from the floor, looks at a photo and removes She's a beautiful woman with large, expressive eyes, but  right now she looks like hell. She stares at the photo -- it's the two couples dancing. A quick glimpse of hurt on face, then her jaw tightens and she rips the picture in h There's muffled talking outside the door, and then two yo boys' voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you come out now, Mommy? Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the half with her and her husband on the dresser then tears the woman off the other half and rips her into pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy, Nick broke my crayon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Lexi hit me and he almost  broke... he almost broke my ear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. arguing "I DID NOT!" "YES YOU DID!" "LIAR!" etc. As that one action siphoned all her energy, Roberta returns bed, gets into fetal position, and stares at a point beyo the wall, ignoring the O.S. voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear that? Your boys need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ASSUNTA GUASPARI (58), Roberta's slender, tired Italian- American mother, stands in the doorway of a well-tended  working-class home, addressing a young NAVAL OFFICER who  holds a lengthy delivery inventory. It's a gray day with  ominous storm clouds. Late 70's CARS are parked on the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have no room for this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, M'am. We have orders to  deliver these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assunta looks beyond the man, dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large wooden CRATES cover her front lawn, and TWO MOVERS  plant down another. They hurry back to the TRUCK, grabbin the next crate too quickly this time. It slips from their hands, CRASHES to the ground and splinters open. Several  VIOLIN CASES spill out. The crate looks like it holds a w lot more.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Instantly a second-story window is flung open, and Robert sticks her head out, a hundred times more energized than  we've seen her so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it, you idiots! Be careful  with those!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men scramble to pick them up. Assunta looks at all th violins, then up at Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why so many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta disappears inside and slams the window shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is filled with boxes shipped from Greece, labelled by the U.S. NAVY. And on the floor, in the middl of the boxes, are FIFTY VIOLIN CASES of various sizes, al with Greek and U.S. NAVY labels. NICK (7) and LEXI (5) cl over the boxes as if they were giant blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Mommy, which box has our toys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERTA'S on the phone, yelling at someone. She's still i the same ratty nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know he's there, so quit  lying to me!... Then check under  Lana Holden -- Mrs. Lana Holden...  Fine. Just tell Lieutenant Demetras  that his wife called and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ASSUNTA grabs the phone from her hand and hangs it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I want you to listen to me. You  can't keep doing this to yourself --  or to the boys. They need their mother  now. You're a beautiful, talented  woman and you have your whole life  ahead of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm so beautiful and talented,  why did Charles leave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because Charles is a big jerk. (beat) Now get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits, leaving Roberta to mull over her words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee is brewing and homemade cinnamon rolls are cooling a rack. We recognize the kitchen from the home movie foot As Assunta clears the boys' breakfast dishes from the tab Roberta enters. She's dressed, but hasn't put on makeup o done much with her hair. It's a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think Charles is a jerk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the day you married him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do you listen to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta half-smiles, pours herself some coffee, then sits down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs, then) What am I gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, you eat breakfast. Second,  you go out and get a job -- any job.  Your boys, god-bless-em, are good  eaters -- but I can't afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, he's gonna get tired of her --  you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assunta's face shows she's doubtful about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well in the meantime, get a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta is behind the counter, meticulously wrapping a pr with ribbons, bows and stickers. At one point she even un a ribbon and redoes it because it's not perfect. She look pretty, but she's dressed conservatively, like a navy  housewife. There's only one other clerk wrapping gifts an long line of impatient customers. A male SUPERVISOR appea behind Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wrap. You're not Picasso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits, and Roberta quickly tries to finish her task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picasso would probably put the bows  on the back of the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks up to find BRIAN TURNER (40), a handsome, s guy with longish hair and a beat-up leather jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian Turner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you moved away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I'm in town for my Mom's  birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand. Roberta misunderstands the gesture and tries to shake his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- that's her gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Oh! Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta hands him the gift she's been wrapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (beat) I heard you had a book published. I  didn't read it but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's O.K. My parents didn't read  it either. It looks good on their  coffee table, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you doing here? I thought  you'd be in Carnegie Hall by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON ROBERTA as she takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta sits opposite Brian. Her lunch is untouched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My college professors said it was  too late -- I hadn't had enough  training to be a concert violinist.  So I got a teaching degree instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet you're a great teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I am. It's just that... (sighs) See, every time I'd get started  somewhere, Charles would be  transferred... then I had my kids  and took time off to raise them...  and then when I decided to teach  again, no one would hire me 'cause  you can't count on a navy wife to  stick around. I finally decided I'd  start my own program -- Charles gave  me the money and I bought fifty  violins from this little Greek shop --  got started at a private school and  then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband ran off with your best  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't my "best" friend. She was  a friend. (beat) Charles is the last person you'd  think would cheat on me -- he never  broke a rule... (a few beats) I wake up one night -- it's like one  in the morning -- and he's not in  bed. I go outside and our neighbor --  this old Greek guy -- is sitting out  there, smoking a cigar, so I ask if  he's seen my husband. "He's taking a  walk with the other officer's wife,"  he says. "He takes a walk every night  with the other officer's wife."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as she gets lost in the memory. She takes a bite o french fry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, these are cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're just gonna wrap presents  and wait for him to come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not very sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to be sexy or be my  friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little of both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta smiles, blushing a bit. Brian looks at her, getti an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I know this really cool  lady who runs this elementary school --  I wrote a piece on her. It's a public  school, but it's alternative -- she  might be able to create some kind of  gig for you. Let me give her a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes his last bite  of sandwich) If she hires you, though, you have  to be willing to relocate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: DA
dialogues.text: A SALSA SONG PLAYS OVER as we see stores with Spanish nam and signs; Black and Latino elementary school children wa home from school; some burned-out buildings; Black and La teens playing basketball on a cement court; Spanish graff on walls; elderly women buying fruit at a produce stand. PULL BACK TO REVEAL this is the POV of Roberta from the b seat of a cab. The SALSA SONG plays on the cab's radio.  Roberta looks scared shitless. Suddenly, two YOUNG MEN flash down the middle of the stre dart IN FRONT of the cab and the driver SLAMS on the brak jerking Roberta forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to East Harlem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANET WILLIAMS, a Black woman (40's) with a kind face, si behind her desk and looks at Roberta's resume. A sign on desk indicates that she's the DIRECTOR. Also on the desk a FRAMED PICTURE of Janet, her husband, daughter (14), an son (12). Roberta sits nervously in the chair opposite he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at resume) Aside from half a term in a private  school -- in Greece -- and a year  teaching chorus in Hawaii -- ten  years ago -- it doesn't look like  you've had any other teaching  experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not traditional teaching  experience. I've been doing private  lessons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet looks for this on the resume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not on there... I taught my  sons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to help you, Mrs. Demetras.  Brian spoke highly of you and I told  him I'd consider starting a violin  class... But without the proper  qualifications, and without any  experience in an inner city school...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta nods, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta stands outside Janet's office, dejectedly watchin the children noisily running through the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta knocks on Janet's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roberta opens the door, we see that Nick and Lexi are  with her. All three have violins. INSIDE, Janet's in  conversation with DENNIS RAUSCH (38), an uptight man with tie that doesn't match his suit jacket. He's showing Jane large scheduling chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt, but I wanted  you to meet my sons -- Nick, Lexi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet smiles at the boys, but clearly thinks Roberta's a  little off. Roberta holds her hand out to Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta Guaspari-Demetras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis shakes her hand, regarding her warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Dennis Rausch, our music  teacher and program coordinator. (beat) Mrs. Demetras, didn't I make things  clear yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could just show you something --  it'll only take a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Janet can answer, Roberta and the kids quickly tak out their violins and get into position. Janet and Dennis exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we having a talent show? I should  have brought my tap shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta ignores the jab, then nods to the boys. The three them begin an incredibly impressive violin trio, playing ETUDE in three-part harmony. For the first measures, Jane still annoyed by the intrusion, but she's quickly won ove Dennis watches impassively. Roberta and the boys finish their piece; Janet applauds a Dennis joins in to be polite. The three take bows. A beat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you hire her now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet laughs, then gestures for them to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you boys been playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I was three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemplates, then) Maybe since I was three and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mom must be a good teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) She's O.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta gives Nick a look, but Janet smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roberta) If you could teach our students to  play like that, I'd be thrilled, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can. Any child can learn the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assuming they had the discipline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll teach them to have discipline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of our parents are struggling  to feed their kids and pay the rent --  they don't have time to help them  learn violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have to. If they can help,  great -- but these kids will be  committed. They'll practice on their  own, they'll help each other in the  classroom --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis laughs. Roberta looks at him, a bit miffed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an edge) I think I know these students, Miss  Demetras. Their attention span doesn't  go past do-re-mi. Maybe on a good  day, I can get them to "fa."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're underestimating them. They  can play as well as any other kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I'd like to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Janet observes the tension, then turns to Roberta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roberta) For now I'll put you down as a sub,  but I have to warn you -- even if it  works out, the Board may not let me  create a permanent position for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's O.K. I'll worry about that  later. (with a grateful look) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see relief -- and fear -- in Roberta's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Janet) Well, I've already planned out the  whole term, and I can tell you right  now, there's no room for this!  Besides, where you gonna find money  for violins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need violins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a noisy music room with bad acoustics, Roberta tries t take control of fifty kids, third through fifth-graders, are in a state of manic excitement over the FIFTY VIOLIN  CASES on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Please do not open the cases, O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ignore her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, can everyone just settle down  and listen to me -- please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - Three girls open their cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to lose it) Keep them closed! Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - Two boys open their cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the boys) Did you hear what I just said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - Three kids are using the violin cases as pretend  machine guns -- and shooting each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put those down, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - A boy and a girl are having a "sword fight" with  their bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the fencers) Don't do that! Put the bows back in  the cases -- right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the SOUND of violin strings being plucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's plucking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta wheels around to find a girl plucking her violin  like a banjo, and doing a little dance. This is LUCY, a s Puerto Rican girl in perpetual motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have I been saying? Put that  away! Back in the case!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta takes a breath. The kids settle down a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K. Thank you. That's much better. (takes another breath) I'll be dividing you into five  classes, but for today --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - A boy plays "bongos" on his violin case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K. -- that's it! You! Stand up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bongo player stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be the first student who  will NOT be in my violin class. Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said OUT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sheepish expression, he exits. The room is finally quiet -- and Roberta's amazed that something worked. She  puffs up a little bit, enjoying the feeling of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else would like to be kicked out  of my class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students stare at her, afraid of her now. DE SEAN, a  small but tough Black boy, raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you raising your hand because  you want to be kicked out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna learn no stupid violin.  It's for wimps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De Sean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, De Sean -- you haven't given  me a good enough reason, so you're  staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of the class, Roberta helps NAEEM, a graceful Bl boy, hold the violin. He has a serious expression and a s on his left cheek. Roberta controls the bow and fingerboa but it appears that the boy is playing music. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I play pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Naeem) See how easy it is? (to the class) Maybe in the spring, we could have a  big concert for your families and  for the whole school. (to the boy) What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naeem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta writes in a notebook and we see that she's measur for violin sizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to class) If you listen to me and do exactly  what I say, you're gonna sound  beautiful at the concert and you're  gonna be so proud of yourselves. (to Naeem) Good, Naeem. Your hand's staying  soft. (to the class) But if you don't listen to me, you'll  sound so bad that your own parents  will feel sick when they hear you.  They might even throw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE KIDS, not used to a teacher speaking like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funky apartment on the Upper West Side. Nick and Lexi a both asleep in sleeping bags on top of a futon on the flo their suitcases nearby. Brian tiptoes past them, carrying two glasses of champagne. He knocks on his office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's in a bathrobe and nightgown, some rollers in he hair. She's tidying up her suitcase, etc., next to an old couch that's been made up as a bed. Leftist political boo line a shelf above Brian's desk, including copies of his  own, TO HELL AND BACK: INTERVIEWS WITH VIETNAM VETS by BR TURNER. His desk is covered with files and books pertaini to MIGRANT WORKERS. Brian enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to champagne) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a toast. (giving her a glass,  holding his up) To Roberta, who's made it through  her first week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clink glasses and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Brian. I'm hanging on  by a thread there. Out of fifty kids,  maybe six are listening to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the progress. Didn't you say  no one was listening to you on Monday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really appreciate all you've done  for us. And I promise -- this weekend  I'll start looking for a place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we've put you out enough. You're  supposed to be writing, not  babysitting for us. (crosses to his desk,  flips through his  Vietnam book) I've started your book. It's very  powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian comes up behind her and starts to kiss her neck.  Roberta's scared -- so she keeps talking, as if it's not  really happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what made you choose migrant  workers for your next book? I mean,  how do you know what to write about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing her neck) I follow my gut, pay attention to  what I'm being drawn to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's aroused, in spite of herself. She turns around faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been waiting to do that since  Mr. Baines' orchestra class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't even notice me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I did. You used to ignore me  and it drove me wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had at least five different  girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't mean I had the one I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a flirtatious smile, then takes out one of h rollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a navy wife anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to takes out another roller and Roberta stops hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I am... legally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And is it a navy requirement that  you dress like it's the 1950's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goading her) Who did you vote for in the last  election?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that have to do with  anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) I don't know. Charles filled out my  absentee ballot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God -- it's even worse than I  thought! (touching her hair) Is this the same Roberta who got the  orchestra to strike until they gave  us new uniforms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs wistfully, then looks a little sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Roberta's not around anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her towards him by the belt to her robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss and it heats up quickly. Roberta pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but... I'm still married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's your husband doing right  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few beats, and she moves towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun streams into the room as Roberta awakens in Brian's b a look of afterglow on her face. She suddenly remembers w she is, and quickly looks at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit -- the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're still sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, relieved, until she sees that Brian's packing suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dashes out. Roberta sits up, rattled by this news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian excitedly gathers papers and files scattered around his electric typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in Texas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to see Roberta in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farm workers. I just got the call --  it came through -- my research grant!  It came through! Isn't that great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places items into a carry-on bag, packing at a rapid c In contrast, Roberta seems to be moving in slow motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a few families lined up  there, some in California --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will you be gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two, three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian throws toiletries into a plastic bag. Roberta enter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought... I just thought you were  gonna be around. And then last night --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops what he's doing and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. Roberta -- last night was great  but did you think I was gonna marry  you in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see in her face that part of her did think that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that... we just got here  and we're barely... I don't even  know where to buy groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian softens as he sees how vulnerable she is. He takes in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna be fine. You have a  job, a place to stay, your kids have  a school to go to -- and there's a  D'Agostino's around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She attempts a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her forehead, then exits. HOLD ON ROBERTA, look hurt and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta rosins her bow, standing in front of ten kids --  third through fifth-grade -- who sit on the floor next to their violin cases. The kids are Black and Latino, with a couple of white faces. They're all talking and ignoring  Roberta except for NAEEM and GUADALUPE, a petite Mexican  girl with a long dark braid. [NOTE: We'll see other violi students from time to time, but this is the class we'll f for Roberta's first year]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what am I doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosining the bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. And what am I doing when I  turn this little screw? (raising her voice) Everyone stop talking. Right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids quiet down. Only Naeem raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naeem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tightening the horse hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touches the heel of  the bow) And what do we call this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, only Naeem raises his hand. Roberta sees him but t to DE SEAN, who's talking to his neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De Sean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we call this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you were but you weren't paying  attention! Do you want people to  think you're stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes De Sean blush -- and it pisses him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Naeem -- tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called the frog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kids giggle and joke about this. Roberta points to t scroll of the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone remember what this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY, the fidgety girl, snaps her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy! Do you like people snapping  their fingers when you're talking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids laugh. Roberta doesn't. She points to the scroll

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jeri curl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta laughs, even though she's trying to be tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis's twenty students play recorder in rows of attache theatre-style seats. Dennis sits at his desk, a METRONOME ticking, and apathetically leads them in scales, using a pen as a baton. He keeps one eye on a stack of quizzes th he's marking, stopping to circle mistakes with the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C-C-C-C, D-D-D-D, E-E-E-E...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - Roberta stands in the hallway at the open door,  dismayed by Dennis' uninspired teaching. She enters and  crosses to Dennis, speaking quietly to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- sorry to interrupt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students immediately start to chatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No talking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back at Roberta, annoyed by her intrusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to take kids out of  Miss Cooper's classroom for my ten  o'clock class -- there's nobody there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Cooper's students have phys ed  on Tuesdays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you scheduled them for violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have read the schedule wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to remain  polite) I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't solve this problem for  you right now. (nods to his class) I'm trying to teach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi and Nick are in Brian's bed. Roberta's tucking in Le he holds a toy truck with Greek writing on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I bring a puppy for show and  tell tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, we don't have a puppy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy said we could get one when we  moved back to America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at Nick, then turns back to Lexi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about your truck? I'll bet you're  the only one in school with a truck  from Greece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's Daddy coming back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta turns to Nick and tucks him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's still on his tour, so  we'll just have to see but... It  shouldn't be too much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he gonna live with us and Brian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey. We're just staying at  Brian's house for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back to Nick who looks worried. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses Lexi, then reaches to turn off the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Leave it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta nods, smiles at her sons, and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine children stand, violins under their right arms, bows hanging down from their right hands, and try to position  their feet as Roberta addresses them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take the right foot and put it  on a tile. Good. Now with the other  foot take a tiny step forward and  put it on a line. Try to make a box  with your feet --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks over to BENJAMIN, a white boy with glasses, and corrects his feet. She sees Lucy dancing in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy! Would you like to leave the  class right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy nods, giggling. Roberta walks down the row of studen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should feel very strong -- so  strong and balanced that if I wanted  to knock you over I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to TANISHA, a sweet-natured Black girl with h hair in tiny braids, and gently pushes her belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? If you're standing strong,  I can't even push you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta turns to De Sean, who's talking to JAMES, a pudgy Black/Puerto Rican boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De Sean! James! Quiet! (as she crosses to  another student) Does anyone know where Naeem is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him this morning but he's not  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know he's not here -- that's  why I'm asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gently pushes Guadalupe's belly. The girl stumbles ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how I pushed you? It means your  feet aren't centered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe tries to correct her feet. Roberta bends down t help and sees that the little girl wears LEG BRACES under her pants. Roberta stands and gestures to one of the boys

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you bring over a chair? (to Guadalupe) It's probably better for you to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy brings the chair. Guadalupe sits, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta walks through a school yard filled with kids and  parents picking them up. She sees Naeem and crosses to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you today, Naeem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't be in violin class anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother won't let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAEEM'S MOTHER, MRS. ADISA, steps INTO FRAME. She's an  attractive Black woman in a dress and head scarf made of  African fabric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son's got more important things  to do than learn dead white men's  music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna learn "Twinkle Twinkle  Little Star"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many Black classical composers  can you name? How many Black classical  violinists do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean it's the way it  should be. Naeem's learning to play  music -- and that makes him feel  good about himself. Why should it  matter who wrote it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mom? Can't I be in the class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Adisa puts a protective arm around her son, then  addresses Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I've seen this before. You  white women come up here and think  you can rescue our poor inner city  children who never asked to be rescued  in the first place. No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks off with Naeem. He glances back at Roberta, the turns away quickly. Roberta watches after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta attempts to read Brian's book, To Hell and Back:  Interviews with Vietnam Vets, but she's distracted. She  glances at her purse, then back to the book. She puts the book down and dials the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian Turner's room, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While she waits, she looks at Brian's picture on the book jacket. There's no answer and she hangs up. She starts to straighten the already clean room, then gets her purse, t out her wallet, and opens it to the plastic covered pictu

dialogues.speaker: PICTURES
dialogues.text: Charles in uniform; a studio shot of the boys when they w 3 and 1; the whole family posed on the terrace of their h in Greece, a view of the ocean behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ROBERTA
dialogues.text: She's really depressed herself now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICE CROWLEY (50's), a no-nonsense Black teacher, shows fifth-graders a globe. She doesn't turn as Roberta enters and crosses to her. In the b.g. we see ROBERTA'S STUDENTS waiting in THE HALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And which ocean is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids simultaneously yell out "ATLANTIC" and "PACIFIC."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... I'm here for the violin  students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icy) You're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a couple of minutes -- I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're having a lesson now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is when they have violin  class!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not my problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's reluctant to argue in front of the kids; she ex

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of noise and chaos as kids run wild during lunch rec Janet rushes through the throngs while Roberta tries to k up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought all the teachers agreed to  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In theory. (to a student) Adam! I want you in my office right  after lunch, you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it! (to Roberta) Whenever you pull kids out, it's a  disruption, plus it's extra work for  the teacher 'cause they have to fill  the kids in on what they missed.  Some teachers resent it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, can't you talk to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet stops walking and pulls a box cutter out of her poc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took this off a second-grader this  morning. I'll help you Roberta --  but I can't hold your hand here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet starts to walk away, then turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A word of advice? When you're picking  up your students, go to Alice's  classroom first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta stands there as Janet walks on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nine children hold their violins in position as Rober addresses them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So pretend you're driving a car and  I'm the policeman and I say STOP!  Thumb up, fingers straight up, flat  palm. Now you be policemen, but turn  your hand and make it say stop to  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE CHILDREN, attempting this. She walks around and he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) You're under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kids crack up and start joking and chatting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock it off, De Sean! (to all) If you kids can't take this seriously,  I don't want you here. I'm teaching  you a difficult instrument because I  respect you and have faith that you  can learn it. But none of that matters  if you don't have respect for  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the children think about what she's saying. A cou uncomfortable with the intensity, hold back giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now turn your wrist so it's flat  against the fingerboard, and that's  how you'll set up your hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta sees Guadalupe struggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe! You've got the violin in  the wrong hand! How did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embarrassed, Guadalupe corrects her position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the small kitchen table, Nick does homework and Lexi p stickers in a sticker book. Roberta's cooking dinner; she grabs a potholder and checks on a bubbling lasagna in the oven. The PHONE RINGS and she answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Bobbi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face falls as she hears the voice. She holds onto the counter to steady herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm, detached) I'm back in the States. I'm at my  parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta closes the oven and gathers her courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch Roberta's body collapse into a sense of overwhel relief. FOLLOW HER as she steps into THE HALLWAY, then  stretches the phone into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She half-closes the door, leans against the sink and star to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through tears) We've missed you so much, Charles.  The boys... they can't wait for you  to come home... I know we'll have a  lot to work out and it won't be easy  right away, but we're gonna get  through this, you know? We're a family  and we belong together and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more emotive than  before) Bobbi -- stop, O.K.? Just stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks as if she's been slapped. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said... you and Lana... you  said it was over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. (beat) It's over between us too, Bobbi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON ROBERTA, devastated. ANGLE on NICK, watching her  through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian's on the phone with Roberta. He's in a t-shirt and  sweats, and his papers are scattered on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't even talk about it! No  explanations, no discussion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta in Brian's living room. She's extremely agitated her eyes are puffy from crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you were still holding  out hope. The guy hasn't called you  or the kids in three months -- I  thought you'd moved on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Maybe not with words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This embarrasses her, then pisses her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I shouldn't have called  you. This was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no -- I'm sorry. Look, I know it  hurts, but you're gonna get through  this, Roberta -- you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm moving back to my Mom's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You're gonna quit teaching in  the middle of the term?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't fit in there -- I'm not making  any progress with the kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna tell Janet --  your husband left you and nothing  else matters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta lies awake on the futon, heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta stands and watches Nick and Lexi sleep. She lies  down beside them and closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta walks through crowds of kids towards Janet who's the middle of confronting a boy student. Janet holds a FI DOLLAR BILL. Roberta hangs back and waits for a chance to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother gave it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would she give you fifty dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To buy breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet gives him a stern look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how hard your mother  works? Do you think it's right for  you steal from her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well let's go call her right now and  ask her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Janet turns to walk off, Roberta crosses to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to speak to you. It's  important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll have to wait. (to the boy) Come on. In my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta watches as Janet dashes off with the boy in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe sits on a chair in the empty room, struggling t set up her violin. Roberta enters, surprised to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe? What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get the stop sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, your teacher's probably looking  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe sighs, then hands Roberta the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't come anymore. It's too hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The violin is hard for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But everyone else is better than me.  I'll always be slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at her sadly and puts the violin in its cas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever hear of Itzhak Perlman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's one of the greatest violinists  in the world, and he has problems  with his legs too. He walks with two  canes -- but he still makes the most  beautiful music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he sits down when he plays?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was your student?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But if he was, I'd tell him the  same thing I'm telling you. You  shouldn't quit something just because  it's hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't stand strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing strong doesn't only mean  using your legs. You can stand strong  on the inside too. (beat) Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe nods. Roberta holds out the violin case. Guadal lunges forward and hugs her around the waist. Roberta  awkwardly accepts the hug, startled and touched by it, an strokes the girl's hair. Guadalupe lets go, takes the vio and exits. HOLD ON ROBERTA as she absorbs what just happe JANET pokes her head into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to speak to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Umm -- that's O.K. It's taken  care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet looks at her curiously, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta walks around an empty, rundown apartment, her  expression somber. Crayon markings on the walls, cigarett burns on the floors, a filthy bathroom and kitchen. An ol Puerto Rican woman stands back as Roberta inspects the pl Roberta wipes grease off one of the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is just for you and your boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No husband? No boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta enters the yard from inside the school. It's fill with kids playing, including Nick and Lexi. She waves to  them and Lexi runs up to her, carrying a piece of artwork

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what I made you, Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a tempera PAINTING of a man's face, the  background decorated with glued-on macaroni. It says DADD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering her  discomfort) That is so beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs off. Roberta exhales, sits down alone on a bench takes out her lunch. She smiles at ALICE CROWLEY and anot TEACHER but they cross to another bench. ISABEL VASQUEZ ( approaches, a lively Puerto Rican woman with a strong New York accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsa matter -- you got cooties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances. (extends a hand) Isabel Vasquez. Second grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta Demetras. I'm the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violin teacher. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down beside Roberta, takes out her lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it my imagination, or does everyone  hate me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to fit in when you're doing  a special program. People figure  you're not gonna be here very long,  so why make the effort? (beat) It may take a while for folks to  warm up, but nobody hates you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) What about Alice Crowley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) A) she thinks the violin's a waste  of time... and B) -- she's a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then there's Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Music Man. You've had the bodacity  to threaten his private little empire --  not to mention the fact that you  messed up his sacred scheduling chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're being nice to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulterior motives. I want my daughter  in your class next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm here next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEXI'S PAINTING is on the wall, along with a crayon drawi of himself, Roberta, and Nick in front of a house. ANGLE - ROBERTA looks out the window. She's gotten some u furniture, cleaned the place, and it's less depressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the street below, three prostitutes stand at the corne Two men sit on a stoop, smoking a joint, and in a parked  car, three men seem to be making a drug deal. One of the  buildings on the street is burned out, missing a front do

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Nick, in his pajamas, enters and crosses to his mother. S smiles at him and they both look out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Greece, we could see the ocean.  Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember. And the fishing boats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the octopuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta smiles and puts her arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Daddy coming here soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta tenses up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's something I've been  wanting to talk to you about. Daddy's  not gonna live with us anymore. You  and Lexi will have special times  when you stay with him, like at  Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell the birthday story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at him, concerned that he's not responding her news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to talk about what I  told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to hear the birthday story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as she contemplates whether to push or not, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the day of Grandpa's birthday,  and I was sad because he had died a  few months back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you knew I'd be born that day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I packed a bag and got all ready --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Daddy laughed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, "It's my father's birthday,  and the baby's gonna be born today."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't believe you. But I was  born. The same day as Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a happy day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was Daddy happy too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, taken aback by the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why is he leaving me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta, overcome with emotion, can barely answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not leaving you, Nick. He loves  you and Lexi very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why can't he live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling) It's very hard to explain... Sometimes  things happen between grown-ups...  and they just can't be together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA moves behind them as they continue to look out the window, and we see Nick move away from his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids play "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star" and they soun awful. Roberta looks disgusted as she leads them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow bows! Slow bows! Don't squeeze!  Stop! Everybody stop! (to De Sean) How much did you practice this week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My asthma -- it was very bad and I  had to go to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again? You told me you went to the  hospital last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Maybe it was last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta rolls her eyes, then turns to Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy -- you sounded the worst of  all. Have you practiced?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You can't be in this class  if you don't practice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandma got mugged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm sorry. Is she O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta stands there, sobered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry, Lucy. (tries to get her  bearings) Just do the best you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of kids stand together with their violins and cha Roberta exits the building and they greet her. She waves  back, but she's clearly still upset by her interaction wi Lucy. She sees Naeem and his mother and approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Naeem. Can I talk to your mom  for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naeem nods and moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I didn't come up here to rescue  anybody. I'm a single mother and I  needed a job. And I know you think  you're protecting your son, but you're  not. I mean, what if Arthur Ashe's  mother had stopped him from playing  tennis because it's a "white man's  game"? (beat) The important thing is that when  Naeem plays music, his whole face  lights up. You should see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Adisa takes this in. Roberta exits. Mrs. Adisa looks for Naeem and sees him watching the violin students, long to be among them. She watches her son with compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta and the boys shop in a colorful outdoor produce m in their neighborhood. The boys suddenly rush over to A MAN sitting on the groun with mixed-breed PUPPIES in a cardboard box. The boys pet them excitedly. Roberta watches her sons; they're happier than she's seen them in ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brown puppy is jumping all over Nick and Lexi who laugh delightedly. Roberta is putting down newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all have to take turns cleaning  up, O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are oblivious to her -- they're in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's SCREAMING at the kids as they play "Twinkle Twi Little Star."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First finger on the E! Three -- two --  one -- open! (to a white girl with  pigtails) Wrong string, Becky! We've done this  fourteen times! And look at your  nails! You're supposed to cut them  for violin class! O.K, everybody  stop! It sounds horrible! I can't  believe how bad it sounds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop playing. Tanisha raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this an important question,  Tanisha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanisha nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have two of those skirts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wore a skirt just like it on  Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the kids crack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Tanisha -- I don't think  that's such an important question. (to class) O.K. Let's try --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Naeem enters with Mrs. Adisa. Roberta  crosses to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naeem and I were wondering if he  could still be in the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love that. (to Naeem) You'll have a lot of catching up to  do. You think you can work that hard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can also arrange some private  lessons at my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have the money for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's O.K. (to Naeem) Why don't you go grab one of my spare  violins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naeem happily runs to the extra violins at the front of t room; Mrs. Adisa nods to Roberta with a look of gratitude then exits. Roberta crosses back to the front of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to class) Let's try it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin again, and we see Naeem take out a violin and  join in. As they play, Roberta's ears perk up at somethin she's hearing. She crosses to Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twinkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to class) Everyone stop! (to Lucy) Let me hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy hesitates, thinking she's in trouble. She plays a ja variation of the song. Roberta smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did someone teach you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I made it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's really great, Lucy. I'm proud  of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to class) All of you -- try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class plays Lucy's jazz variation and Naeem happily j in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta sits opposite Janet and MRS. LAMB, a white woman her 30's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shouting at them. All the  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all the time. But if they don't  listen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you tell them that they were  making their parents sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet raises her eyebrows at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't exactly what I said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm raising Becky in a supportive  atmosphere. I don't send her to school  to be abused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to discipline them.  If they're gonna learn an instrument,  they need to take it seriously --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what Mrs. Lamb is trying to  say, Roberta, is that you're a little  too harsh. I'm sure you might be  able to soften some of your comments  to the children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives Roberta a long hard look. Roberta nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta listens to the students play "Go Tell Aunt Rhody" badly. They finish and stare at her, afraid of her respon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that was... that was pretty  good... that wasn't too bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at her in disbelief, then look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't? I thought we stunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't put it that way... You  all just need to practice a bit more. (to James) James, have you practiced this week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy nervously shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you please try a little harder  for next week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James nods. The kids are baffled by her politeness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Just do the best you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you acting like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want a nice teacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already got nice teachers. You  added some variety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We like you better the way you  used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (to Becky) What about you, Becky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. This is even worse. You're  acting weird now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then -- I take it back. You  all stunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't tell your parents I said  so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas MUZAK plays in the b.g. as Roberta kisses and h Lexi and Nick goodbye. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT stands nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you come with us? Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I told you. This is Daddy's  special time with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi looks upset; Nick is stoic. Roberta hugs them one la time. The FLIGHT ATTENDANT steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take good care of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FLIGHT ATTENDANT escorts them into the jet way. Rober holds back tears as they get further away from her. At th last moment, Lexi turns and waves; Nick does not. Roberta waves, tears starting to fall, and the boys disappear fro sight. She observes all the families travelling together, and feels like the loneliest person in the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta enters her apartment, back from the airport, and  double-locks the door behind her. You can see on her face that she's dreading the emptiness. She crosses to a small Christmas tree, obviously decorated by her and the boys, plugs in the tiny blinking lights. It's not exactly  Rockefeller Center. She turns on the T.V., playing IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE. She crosses to the kitchen, then returns with a carton of eggnog, a glass, and a bottle of rum. She sits down on th couch, pours herself some eggnog, adds rum, adds more rum goes back into the kitchen, returns with nutmeg, sprinkle some on top, then drinks. She sighs, glancing miserably a the tree and the T.V. Pathetic. She couldn't look any les festive if she tried. There's a KNOCK on the DOOR. Roberta gets up and warily approaches the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa Claus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks through the peephole, then quickly unlocks the  door and opens it, revealing BRIAN, giving her a big smil He looks sexy as hell (even with a silly lit-up Santa Cla pin on his leather jacket), and he holds a long-stemmed r rose in one hand, and a Christmas present in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's thrilled and relieved to see him. She embraces  him, and they kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON plaster walls being knocked down with sledgehamm REVEAL Brian, Roberta, and a couple of workmen knocking d the walls in an old brownstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mild winter day. Roberta, covered with plaster dust and overheated from working, leans against a car and drinks a beer. The three-story brick building has some graffiti on and is badly in need of a paint job; there are a few brok windows, and the front stairs need repairing. WORKMEN fil in and out. We can see from the STREET SIGNS that we're o 118th STREET, a few houses off FIRST AVENUE. Brian (also dust-covered), Nick and Lexi toss around a  football. LAWRENCE (6), a Black boy who lives next door,  joins them. Brian crosses to Roberta, sweaty and out of  breath. He takes a swig of her beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., enough goofing off -- back to  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trying to kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs and they kiss. ASSUNTA comes up the street with a bag of take-out food. casts a dubious glance at the lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the only person in the whole  coffee shop not speaking Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta rolls her eyes. O.S. a car BACKFIRES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear that? Gunshots! How you  gonna live here by yourself? (calling) Boys, come eat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work in this neighborhood, Mama. I  want to live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys approach and Assunta hands them sandwiches. Lawr hangs back. Assunta calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hungry, Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawrence nods and she hands him a sandwich. Roberta smile at her mother's gesture. The kids move off to Lawrence's  front steps and Assunta gives Roberta and Brian sandwiche

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brian) Why did you let her buy this house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, your daughter does what she  wants -- or haven't you noticed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert washes dishes and Assunta dries. The leftovers fro an Italian dinner are on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't understand the rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having my own place will make me  feel like I'm really starting my  life again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you invested your divorce  settlement, you could buy something  nice someday. It's bad enough that  you've been renting in this  neighborhood, but to lock yourself  into a mortgage --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) Mama, please. Just stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assunta backs off. Roberta feels guilty and moves to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, O.K.? Besides, if things  keep going well, I'm sure eventually  Brian will move in with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few beats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you know about this man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian's a good person, he's helped  me a lot, he's great with the boys --  since he got back to town, it's been  really sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an attitude) And how long has he been back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not very long. Don't make the  same mistake twice, Bert. You barely  knew Charles when you married him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) I don't get it -- you're ragging on  me about buying the house -- I would  think you'd want Brian to live with  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if he's the wrong person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta locks her jaw, not wanting to believe that she's  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids play "Allegro," Roberta leading them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get ready, now -- we're coming up to  the fermata...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach a certain note, then pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold... Hold... Don't anybody move.  Now at the Spring Concert, the  audience is gonna be dying for that  next note -- but we'll make them  wait. As a matter of fact, I think  I'll go grab a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts for the door and the kids moan and groan: "Com on, Roberta!" "Roberta, get back here!" She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, O.K. But you have to promise  you'll all start together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. They begin again -- all at different times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man. We'll never get that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a very nice thing to say  about your classmates. (to class) How many people think they can get  it right by the concert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the kids raise their hands. De Sean looks around,  embarrassed, then raises his too. Roberta smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and Roberta finish making love on the futon. They l in each other's arms, still breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian makes a sound that's either panting or laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you just laugh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at him, offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do people feel like the minute  something's going great, they gotta  name it? (beat) Once you name something, you snuff  the life out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disentangles from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Brian. Do you still get away  with that crap? It's not the Sixties  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe if you'd actually gone  through the Sixties, you'd know what  I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! We won't name it, we won't  talk about it, we'll act like we  have no feelings for each other  whatsoever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She angrily turns on her side with her back to him. Brian regrets hurting her and moves to her, kissing her shoulde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm being an asshole. (sweetly teasing) You can say you love me if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs and coaxes her to kiss him -- a temporary truce

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ERNIE (70's), a rickety Black man in work boots, looks ba by a tangled mess of wires protruding from a wall. Robert approaches.
