dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it coming, Ernie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if I could just remember what  I did here yesterday, I'd be moving  a whole lot faster. (beat) You look real pretty today, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian overhears, rolls his eyes and pulls her aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. Why did you hire him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needed a job. Besides, he's wired  all of East Harlem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? Fifty years ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian sighs and walks off into another room. Two MEN carr in large panels of sheetrock with old WALLPAPER on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is there wallpaper on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how it comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lean the panels against a wall. Roberta turns to Ern

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, that's how it comes now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys quickly exit. Brian re-enters and sees the panel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheetrock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've gotta be kidding. Those ex- cons you hired ripped this off --  and you too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta feels stupid but doesn't want to show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- this house is taking every  penny of my settlement. I can't afford  fancy union workers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing up his hands) Fine. Do it your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stomps off. ANOTHER ANGLE - Nick watches them fight an looks distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of screaming and commotion as the kids crowd around fight in progress. As we move through the crowd we see th NICK's in a fight with another boy; Nick's nose is bleedi and he has the boy in a headlock. TWO TEACHERS run over t break it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick sits outside, holding an ice pack to his bloody nose

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta stands opposite Janet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving him a two-day suspension --  but next time he'll be expelled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There won't be a next time -- I  promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you noticed your son lately?  He's tied up in knots and he needs  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet, kids fight. You're making too  much of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was choking the kid. (beat) Nick's in trouble, Roberta. You need  to deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta takes this in, upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta plays "Go Tell Aunt Rhody" with Guadalupe, De Sea Naeem, Benjamin, and two kids from the other classes. Lex plays along with them. Nick enters from the kitchen, eati a cookie, ignoring the students. He turns on the T.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to students) Keep playing, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta crosses to Nick and shuts off the T.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can watch when we're done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my house! They don't live here --  I do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Nick honey -- the kids are real  nervous about the Spring concert.  You could probably give them some  pointers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for the T.V. dial and she stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses back to her students; Nick turns on the T.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, Nick and Lexi laugh as they play frisbee alongside DUCK POND. Roberta watches, relieved to see Nick enjoying himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good catch Nick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick throws it back to Brian and it lands in the WATER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock sternly) Uh-oh. You know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stalks towards Nick menacingly, picks him up and prete he's going to throw him into the water. Nick laughs  hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through laughter) Don't! Don't throw me in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsa matter? Afraid of a little  water? The ducks aren't afraid! Are  you a chicken or a duck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't! Don't throw me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you got yourself a chicken,  Roberta!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a chicken!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then you must be a duck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pretends again to throw Nick in, then puts him down. L holds out his arms to Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw me in the water, Brian! Do it  to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian swoops him up and Lexi starts laughing. Roberta lau along, happy to see the affection between Brian and her s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian and Roberta speak as they stroll; the boys run ahea of them, dragging sticks along the pavement. In the b.g. see HARLEM STREETS bordering the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to be the only one who can  get Nick to laugh these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He misses his dad. I'm just a  surrogate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I think Nick really likes you. (taking his arm) You know... we're all hoping you'll  move into the new house with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. Can we just slow down here a  minute? It's too much like getting  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so bad about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kind of commitment just isn't  realistic. I mean, how can we know  that you and I will even be able to  stand each other in five years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we don't. But if two people  care about each other, they take a  chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And look what happened to you and  Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about Charles. I'm  talking about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Roberta. Marriage is based on  a belief that one person can  completely meet another person's  needs. I just don't buy that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is making her nervous. She looks at him, afraid of w he might be saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) What are you saying? If there's some  need you have that I don't meet,  you'd go and get it "met" by someone  else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heaves a sigh of frustration, not wanting to answer th question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying that it's the 80's and  it's a fantasy to think of marriage  lasting these days. One out of two  marriages ends in divorce!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't answer my question. (beat) If I don't meet all your needs, and  we're in a committed relationship --  forget marriage for a minute; I'm  just talking about a relationship --  would you go to someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In theory, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In theory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks very disheartened. Brian feels badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta, we've got something good  right now -- that's the important  thing. Let's just keep it that way,  O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her to him, kissing her neck, but she pulls away from him. ON NICK, observing with an anxious expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whining) Why can't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks distressed by her talk with Brian as she an the boys enter, back from the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just can't, O.K.? Brian's at his  house tonight, and we're at ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then I wanna go to his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough, Nick. Now why don't you and  your brother practice while I make  dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel like practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well do it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna go to Brian's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop whining, and get your violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick stomps off to get his violin. Lexi follows. Roberta  puts down her bag and takes off her coat. While Lexi sets his violin, Nick opens his violin case, takes out the vio and angrily starts playing, loudly and roughly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem with you is you're mean  to everybody and then they don't  want to be with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard just about enough from  you, young man. Now set your violin  up properly and start practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick THROWS the violin against the floor. Roberta's  speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate the violin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pick that violin up right now  and don't you ever ever --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick picks up the violin and THROWS the violin down even  harder, then YELLS at Roberta before she can even respond

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all your fault! You made Daddy  leave and you're gonna make Brian  leave too! You're gonna be all alone  and I'll have to take care of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta is stunned. The anger drains out of her as she  suddenly sees what this is all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick -- you don't have to take care  of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who's going to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of myself -- and I'll  take care of you and Lexi. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't try hard enough. You made  Daddy leave us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hits her in the solar plexus. Her hurt and vulnerabi start to pour out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true. I begged him not to  leave, but he didn't listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta hesitates, but knows she has to tell them the tru She addresses both boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father met someone he liked  more than Mommy, and then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta swallows, shocked to hear him ask this. She can h answer him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lana. Remember our friends Lana and  Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he gonna marry her now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but he's not coming back... to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Lexi look very upset, not only from hearing the  finality in her words, but from seeing their mother's pai Roberta moves closer to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of you, Nick. You  too, Lexi. I promise. I'm not going  anywhere. We're still a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick starts crying. Roberta takes him in her arms. Lexi s to cry and Roberta holds him too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, to both) I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie's radio plays a BLUES SONG. The BRICK WORKERS radio plays SPANISH MUSIC, and the PAINTERS' radio plays a RAP  SONG. Roberta stands in the middle, about to lose her min HER POV - Ernie sits on a stool facing his wiring. He's f asleep. ANOTHER ANGLE - The brick workers build a crooked fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Roberta sighs heavily, then crosses to the painters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What color is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you Eggshell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eggshells are white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian watches this interaction as he sands a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an idiot! I told you -- you  can't be your own contractor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I'm an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to Ernie and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, Ernie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her groggily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to the brick workers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to the painters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian smiles at her, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's more like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Brian. I mean it. I need to be  with a man who can make a commitment  to me. I need that, and my sons need  that. (beat) So can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) Roberta --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone and expression tell her the words are not  forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, shocked by her toughness, but knows he c give her what she wants. He exits. Roberta stands in the  middle of the room, a determined look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: Stands in the aisle, leading the students and playing vio

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: The fifty fifth-grade students play the "Twinkle" variati Their playing is impeccable and they look terrific. As the CAMERA PANS the audience, we recognize: MRS. ADISA tears in her eyes as she watches Naeem; MRS. LAMB and her husband, watching Becky in amazement; ISABEL and her daug sitting with ASSUNTA, NICK and LEXI; JANET, impressed as  hell; and DENNIS, seething with jealousy. As the kids sta the jazz variation of "Twinkle," a WOMAN elbows her husba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one Lucy wrote!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA returns to the children and captures their own pride in their playing, including LUCY, who smiles as she hears her song played by fifty.

dialogues.speaker: THE CONCERT
dialogues.text: The students are now playing "Allegro," and they reach th fermata. They hold their positions in silence and the aud watches in anticipation. Roberta cues them and they play next note in perfect unison. An involuntary smile lights DE SEAN's face. They finish the song, the audience applau and Roberta turns to face them. She lights up when she sees how thrilled Janet looks, and Janet in turn raises her hands higher as she applauds Rob

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The side of the building now has an impressive mural: an  urban landscape with three super heroes -- Puerto Rican,  Black, and white -- rising up out of the street. It reads ONLY THE STRONG SHALL SURVIVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta stands in front of a classroom of twenty cute fir graders -- mostly Black and Latino, a few white -- sittin on the floor, chatting excitedly. Even though Roberta's t years older, she seems more youthful; her wavy hair is lo over her shoulders, her clothing's casual and artistic. B her is Janet, her hair flecked with gray, and Dennis, who looks pretty much the same. The classroom teacher is ISAB a little older, a little tougher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon everybody, settle down -- Janet  wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today's a very special day because  we're starting the tenth year of the  East Harlem Violin Program. This is  a wonderful opportunity for you, so  I want you to talk to your parents  about whether you'd like to try this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter took violin with Roberta  when she was your age, and now she's  in high school and she still talks  about how much she loved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet and I started this program  because we knew how much you kids  could benefit from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUTAWAY to Roberta and Janet exchanging glances over Denn taking credit for the program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know, however, that the  violin is a difficult instrument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUSTIN, a Black boy with attitude, raises his hand. He al wears a puffy red, yellow and green crocheted beret. Isab nods to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that lady in the back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - DOROTHEA (Doro-taya) VAN HAUFTEN (40's), an elega beautiful woman, smartly dressed, takes photographs from back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Dorothea Van Hauften --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what? What kinda name is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justin -- sshh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and she's taking pictures of  Roberta's classes for a magazine  article about music education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna be in the magazine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First things first, Justin. Roberta's  gonna explain to you about the  "lottery."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta steps forward. RAMON OLIVAS (7), a small, adorabl Puerto Rican boy with a crew cut, watches her with adorat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to just teach fifty kids at  this school. But now I teach a hundred  and fifty kids at three East Harlem  schools and there's so many children  who want to take violin classes that  we have to have a lottery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VANESSA raises her hand, a white girl whose clothes and  accessories are always adorned with cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be in the class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's explaining that. Just  listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After your parents sign your  permission slips, I'm gonna put them  in a sack, and I'll pick fifty names  from each school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - Ramon listens intently with his fingers crossed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So everyone bring in your slips by  Friday, and I'll come back and tell  you who's in violin class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, she's just picking names  from a hat. It doesn't mean that  anyone's better than anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMON raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roberta) I really really hope that I get in  the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at him, struck by his sweetness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brownstone looks a lot better than when we last saw i Graffiti's been removed, the stairs have been repaired, t windows have security bars, and there are flowers bloomin in pots in front of the building. Roberta steps INTO FRAM walking Allegra, now a 10-year-old dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is transformed: the first floor is one long ope room with oak floors, a living room in front with a beaut fireplace and a grand piano, and a country kitchen in the rear, complete with pots hanging over a large butcher blo NICK (17) practices cello and LEXI (15) practices piano;  they play Haydn's "Trio #13." Now handsome young men, the blonde hair has darkened to brown. Nick is huskier; Lexi a slighter build. Both are passionate, talented musicians On the couch, RACHEL (12), a mature, beautiful Black girl rosins her bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you guys don't play the  violin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, picture her being your teacher  and your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel cracks up but stifles her laughter as Roberta ente from outside with Allegra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Rachel. Be right with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roberta removes Allegra's leash, Rachel and Lexi share conspiratorial look. In the b.g., Nick packs up his cello

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nick) You're gonna practice upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already? You've barely practiced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- are you timing me with a  stop watch? Why don't you pick on  Lexi for a change?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I'm perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick jostles him and heads upstairs. Lexi gets up from th piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rachel) Have a good lesson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to a sharp-looking bike parked behind the fron door and addresses Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back in a couple of hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi mouths "be careful" along with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi plays basketball with a group of Black and Latino gu Despite his small stature, he's a great athlete, and an  accepted part of the group. The game ends. He and his bud Lawrence (now 16), both all sweaty, cross to a water foun As Lexi takes a drink --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I try your bike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi wipes his mouth and looks up at HENRY (18), a tall,  intimidating Black teenager who towers over him. Lawrence watches tensely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be leaving pretty soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanna take it for a spin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Henry -- he don't want to  loan you his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear him say that. (to Lexi) Is that true? Did you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi looks at him, knowing there's only one right answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta and Rachel play Bach's "Minuet One" together on t violin. The girl has obvious talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vibrato... don't wiggle your wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel stops, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dang! I can't get that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You almost have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost isn't good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I turn you into such a  perfectionist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I came that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, then) Just as long as you get it right for  your Julliard audition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've recommended you for a gifted  kids scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel looks at her in wide-eyed gratitude. ANGLE - Lexi enters the front door, a glum look on his fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the bike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta drives with Nick in the front, Lexi and Lawrence the back. They're in a dangerous looking part of East Har

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, please. Don't do this to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Mom -- why don't you let me  handle this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we getting closer, Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the next block up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roberta) You don't have to do this. I'll pay  you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? It took me six months to save  up for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help him, O.K.? We'll both pay  you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or we'll ask Dad -- he'll help us  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., slow down. It's the second one  on the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta slows the car down next to a HOUSING PROJECT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a place you'd want to go into, even in the day time. PULL BACK TO REVEAL this is their POV from INSIDE THE CAR The boys look frightened, but Roberta's on a mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Mom, let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she exits. The boys watch as she heads for the buildi then Lexi shakes his head and covers his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dead. She's gonna get me killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick jumps out of the car and heads after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Get back in the car and stay  with the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick hesitates and heads back. Roberta presses on. Lawren opens the window and calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take the stairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE ELEVATOR DOOR with a handwritten SIGN that r OUT OF ORDER. WIDER - Roberta stands in front of the elevator, staring  tensely at the sign. She takes a deep breath, then heads the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta climbs the dimly-lit stairs of a dilapidated, sca building. O.S. a BABY CRIES, a couple of TV's BLARE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the top of the stairs, Roberta turns down the hall, pa a door riddled with bullet holes. She finds the apartment and knocks. No response. She knocks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a school teacher. Henry has taken  my son's bicycle and I want it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then the door cracks open, an OLD WOMAN visible  through the chain lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you tell Henry that if he returns  the bike, I won't have to notify the  police -- or his school principal.  Although since I am a teacher, it  would be very easy for me to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of beats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not home. He doesn't get home  till late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not till after ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be on the steps of CPE 1 at 11  P.M. I'll be waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes. Roberta exhales. Did she just do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta, Nick, Lexi and Lawrence sit on the front steps o the school. The street is deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. He's not gonna show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta sits confidently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he actually cares that  you're a teacher? You think he even  goes to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Mom -- let's just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only five after eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Lexi roll their eyes and exchange a look: she's  nuts. Suddenly, there's the SOUND of a bicycle. Nick, Lex and Lawrence look towards the sound, incredulous. Lexi st Henry rides up on the bike and dismounts. Lexi looks dire at him as he takes the bike from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just borrowing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at Roberta, then walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta stands in front of Isabel's class and calls out n handing the selected children acceptance letters. The kid are charged up; "My heart is pounding!" "Please pick me!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shandra Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pretty Black girl with braids and tons of barrettes jum up and down, then runs up for her letter. The kids SQUEAL and CHEER for each student called. Shandra hugs her best  friend MYESHA, a chubby Black girl who also holds a lette

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justin Brady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUSTIN raises his fists in triumph. ANGLE - RAMON anxious waits to see if his name will be called. JUSTIN sits down next to him, waves his letter in Ramon's face, taunting h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa Klein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa takes her letter and smiles. She puts it into her cat-shaped backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K. One more name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon crosses his fingers and holds his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonard Hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMON looks crushed. JUSTIN taunts him some more. LEONARD scrawny white boy takes his letter, scared by it. He star to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too hard! I don't wanna do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you even wanna try, Leonard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through tears) I don't want to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabel looks at Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, O.K. then. I'll pick someone  else. (she picks a name) Ramon Olivas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon's face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roberta walks through the yard, she sees kids excitedl showing acceptance letters to their moms. SHANDRA and MYESHA hold hands as they run to Shandra's mo BEVERLY WILSON, pushing a stroller. She looks at the lett and hugs Shandra. ANGLE - RAMON reads his letter to his mother, CONCEPCION  (45), whose eyes tell you that she's lived through a lot. She speaks with a Puerto Rican accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is to inform you that your child,  Ramon Olivas, has been chosen by  lottery to be in the violin program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon spins round and round with the letter in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta illegally parks her old Honda, rushes out of the  car, grabs her book bags and three violins, pulls a parki ticket from her pocket and puts it on the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (German accent) Does that really work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta turns. It's DOROTHEA, the PHOTOGRAPHER we saw in classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I keep trying. And maybe  someday the school will give me a  parking space!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes towards the school and Dorothea follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Roberta a thin box. Roberta puts down her violi glances inside it and forgets about being late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Terrific black and white shots of Roberta's advanced  classes playing violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, these are great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those copies are for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Can I... pay for you them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. Besides -- you'll  need your money for parking tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're doing for these children  is wonderful. My husband's a violinist --  he was quite impressed when I told  him about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arnold Steinhardt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the Guarneri String Quartet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea nods, and hands Roberta a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay in touch. Let us know when the  kids have a concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL, heading for school, calls out to Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be late for violin class! I  hear the teacher's really mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta smiles, slips the card in her pocket, nods to Dor and follows Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's advanced class plays "Can-Can." Rachel's one of the eight sixth-graders. Roberta plays along, crossing to AMANDA, a white girl in a country-western outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda, what did I tell you about  wearing cowboy boots to violin class?  They're too slippery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to a pudgy Black/Puerto Rican boy with glasse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax your two, Simon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances at STEPHANIE, a white girl with red hair, nex to KENNY, a Black boy with an earnest expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your stop sign has to be up, Kenny!  Stephanie, it doesn't look like you  ever had a lesson with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLOS (13) hurries in, a handsome Black boy in a basebal jacket that says "LOS LEONES." He looks 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your violin, Carlos?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nervously looks down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, is it walking here by itself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Black third-grade girl rushes into the room and hands C his violin, then runs off. Roberta crosses to Carlos as h quickly readies the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your buddies giving you a hard time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's just not cool. You wouldn't  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you want your sister to carry  your violin, that's fine. But is she  practicing for you too? Because  lately, that's how it sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been busy! I've been --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested! Just get here on  time, and commit to this class or I  don't want you in here, you  understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods sullenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good violinist, Carlos --  and it's definitely not "cool" to  waste your own talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos takes this in as Roberta crosses to another studen

dialogues.speaker: NIG
dialogues.text: It's upstairs from a grocery store on a busy street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon sits on the floor, upset, half-heartedly building w Legos, while his parents argue in the KITCHEN. His father MANUELO is a stocky, muscular man. INTERCUT between the t areas. This is a modest, well-kept apartment. Off the kit religious candles burn on a shelf above a washing machine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you show it to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just needed one parent's signature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with some Spanish) Well, I'm his parent and I don't  give permission! He should be playing  baseball, not the violin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes him happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON RAMON, looking far from happy at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel steps off a city bus, carrying her violin. She pas two sixth-grade boys and a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) Ooh, check out little Miss Violinhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She carry that violin with her all  the time 'cause she think she special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel turns to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She proudly continues on, then sees Roberta walking towar the school and catches up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonchalant) So I heard from Julliard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta stops and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta gives her a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE BEGINNER'S CLASS, including Ramon, as they play  "Lightly Row." Roberta walks around, making corrections a she addresses the students. She doesn't see Justin poking Ramon with his bow; Ramon swats the bow away and glares a his nemesis. Roberta moves some of Shandra's braids away  from the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when you take the violins home,  tape your music to the wall directly  in front of your nose so you can  play with perfect posture. Your  parents are gonna be so excited to  hear you play!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREECHING comes from Ramon's room as he practices "Light Row." His brothers, PEDRO (18) and ERNESTO (17), cringe a they try to watch T.V. Ernesto gives up and puts on his  Walkman; Pedro's ready to break the violin. Concepcion li patiently as she folds laundry, but even she winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Ramon! How many cats you killing in  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT RAMON - He plays with pride, eyes on the music t to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON RAMON, his improved playing showing that time has pass WIDER - the beginner's class plays "Lightly Row." JUSTIN is struggling more than the other students. Robert plays along with the class, eyeing each student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More bow! To the frog! Myesha, your  stop sign line should be touching.  Don't let it wiggle! You're on the  wrong string, Justin! And look at  your feet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa enters the front door without her violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your violin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye! And you may be dropped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa pouts and exits. Roberta moves to ROSARIO, a Puer Rican girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at those nails, Rosario!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls a clipper from her pocket and swiftly clips the MYESHA nervously glances at her own nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you over there, Myesha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves to Ramon and corrects his bowing position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ramon) You're doing much better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roberta walks on to the next student, Justin purposely knocks over Ramon's music stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop dead, Justin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a accident!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon, I don't like that kind of  talk. Justin, pick up his stand,  now! Our spring concert is in three  weeks and you might not be in it. Is  that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roberta heads for her car, she sees Vanessa being help into a car by her FATHER, his suit wrinkled and tie loose There's SNOW on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Klein? I'm gonna have to drop  Vanessa from the class if she keeps  forgetting her violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) She's going back and forth between  houses. My wife and I split up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softening) Oh. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta leans into the car window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa, maybe you could write down  for your Mom and Dad which days are  violin days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost in tears) The tape doesn't stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I taped the music to the wall at my  Mom's house and then I took it to my  Dad's house and it doesn't stick  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Klein's eyes tear up and he quickly wipes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you know what? That's an easy  problem to solve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks through her book bag, takes out a piece of musi and gives it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you have two, O.K.? One for each  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa nods, clutching the piece of music. Roberta and M Klein exchange a look. She touches his arm, then walks of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon, holding his bow and violin, crosses to his father  who's watching a baseball game on T.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna hear my new song, Papa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Not right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon exits, hurt. Concepcion watches from the side, and  crosses to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made mistakes with Pedro and  Ernesto and we can't fix them now,  but Ramon -- he works so hard. The  violin makes him want to be good at  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows no response, and she exits. Manuelo ponders what she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta approaches the school on a winter morning. She sm as she sees Vanessa get out of her MOTHER'S car with her  violin. Roberta nears the front door and finds Isabel and some teachers huddled in conversation. A few students are crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Isabel) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beginners sit on the floor and rosin their bows. A fe chat, but it's quieter than usual, except for RAMON who i "blessing" kids with his violin bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to heaven... You go to hell...  You go to hell... heaven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta enters slowly. She looks very shaken up. She take note of what Ramon is doing, and overhears Toussaint and  Shandra in mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandpa died and my uncle, so  that makes six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know more than that. At least seven  people... maybe even nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta gently tells Ramon to sit, and then she sits down a child-sized chair in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I know that you've all heard the bad  news about Justin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a drive-by shooting by his  house and he got shot on accident  and he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myesha takes this in, looking sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anyone want to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) I think we should just play violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concepcion cooks chicken and Pedro sets the table, whistl along to Ramon's O.S. violin playing "We Shall Overcome." There's a KNOCK on the door. Concepcion answers it, revea Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta! Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came by to check on Ramon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't he tell you what happened at  school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concepcion shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon is still playing violin as Concepcion and Roberta e When he sees Roberta he straightens up even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta wants to talk to you, O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods. Concepcion touches his head, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did that sound O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon smiles, pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about Justin.  Remember how mad I got the last time  I saw him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You got very strict with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't always so easy to be nice  to him, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon looks away from her, upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Justin's in heaven or hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon runs his fingers along his bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him to drop dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta touches Ramon's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justin didn't die because of what  you said. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you're that powerful,  do you? I mean, if you had such  powers, just imagine what kind of  violin player you'd be by now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'd be better than you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh together, then Ramon looks sad again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's O.K. to cry, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boys still cry and they're big,  strong young men now. (beat) I bet Justin's daddy cried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon's eyes get teary. Roberta quietly leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta brings in the mail, looking curiously at a manila envelope with a return address from the NY REVIEW OF BOOK She opens it, looks inside, then pours out a batch of oth letters onto the table. They're addressed to BOX HOLDER 1 She opens one, reads it, then rushes to an INTERCOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick, Lexi! Get down here right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just trying to help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Lexi stand by the table, opposite Roberta -- wit the incriminating pile of letters between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is humiliating!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, no one knows it's you! I mean,  you don't even have to read them if  you don't want to. (glances at pile) Although obviously, a lot of guys  are interested in dating you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. A lot of guys are interested in  dating you and Lexi. (beat) What did you say about me, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They thought she'd never ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Beautiful musician, late 40's, tired  of playing solo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- seeks a healthy, stable, attractive  man who's not afraid of a duet with  a strong, independent woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My violin playing will feed your  soul...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And my lasagna will be music to  your palate."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They beam with pride. Roberta looks at them, mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you catch all the music metaphors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's a little weird  that you're trying to get your mother  a date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's a little weird  that you're not even interested in  dating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, look. Number one -- even if I  wanted to date, I don't have time.  And number two -- I've got my  teaching, I've got you guys -- that's  all I need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys nod, disappointed, and she exits. They look at e other with glum expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nick) I really thought she'd like the music  metaphors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta lies on the couch, reading the personal ad letter She tosses one aside, then opens another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The letter is designed like a newspaper with a headline t reads: JOURNALISM PROFESSOR DAN PAXTON ANSWERS PERSONAL A

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Roberta can't help but be charmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta, Nick and Lexi play Haydn's "Trio #13" together o their respective instruments. We sense that this is a spe family ritual. They play throughout their conversation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're flat, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The B sounded flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just play the violin, Mom. I'll take  care of the cello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They play for a few beats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You nervous, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL rings and Roberta jumps up, bolting into the bathroom down the hall. Lexi and Nick exchange a smile, then Lexi crosses to the  door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing in the doorway is a man in casual college profes attire. He's nice-looking, but no Prince Charming. He sha Lexi's hand and smiles warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Dan Paxton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi shows him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE MIRROR - Roberta takes a last look at herself,  wondering if he'll find her attractive. She touches her h adjusts her dress, then takes a deep breath as she builds her courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta enters the living room where Dan is chatting with Nick and Lexi. Dan sees her and is instantly smitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her hand) Wow. An honest woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your ad. When you said you were  beautiful, you were telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, blushing, and avoids eye contact with her son who are trying really hard not to laugh. As she and Dan s to exit:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure you're home by midnight,  young lady.

dialogues.speaker: CLOCK
dialogues.text: It reads 12:30. WIDER - Nick and Lexi play a video game on the TV screen. O.S., there's the SOUND OF A CAR. They race to the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten bucks he tries to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a no-brainer. Of course he'll  try. The real question is whether  she'll let him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K. -- ten bucks she lets him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare out the window intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan pulls his car up in front of Roberta's house. Beside  him, Roberta holds a program from a Lincoln Center concer Roberta's tense, but Dan seems relaxed and centered in hi attraction to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a lot of fun tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I did too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a confession -- I've never  answered an ad before. I did it on a  dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have a confession -- my boys  placed the ad behind my back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both laugh, then smile at each other. An awkward bea will he or won't he? Dan leans in to kiss her, and Robert turns away, uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Dan -- I went along with this  'cause it's been a while. Quite a  while... And I had a very nice time...  but I'm not sure if I'm ready to get  involved with anyone right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Roberta feels badly about rejecting him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Does this mean I don't get any  lasagna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta cracks up. Dan smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta enters. The boys are back to their video game,  covering that they've been spying on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you guys still up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all innocence) Why? Is it late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good try, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... he's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nice"? As in "let's just be friends"  nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet. We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick looks disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's still a lot more letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts heading upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom -- can you loan me ten  dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BLACKBOARD reads: SPRING CONCERT IN 10 DAYS! PRACTICE

dialogues.speaker: PRACTICE PRACTICE
dialogues.text: Roberta rushes in, frazzled, not noticing at first that t beginners are very quiet -- and that most don't have viol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, I'm so sorry -- I got stuck  over at CPE 2...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her stuff down, then looks at the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Where are all your  violins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard you got fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet and Dennis talk outside Janet's office. Roberta sto over to them. Janet looks at her, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come in my office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true? You're firing me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not me, Roberta. The Board of  Ed. cut the budget, the District had  to comply, and as of the end of this  term, the violin program has been...  excessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta takes this in, momentarily speechless. In the b.g the beginners slip into the hall to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excessed. (beat) They specifically said that my violin  program has to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've slashed the budget -- music  and art programs got hit the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Dennis' classes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tenured, Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at him, then back to Janet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was this decided?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things happened very quickly... I  wanted to tell you myself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reeling) I just... I can't even believe this  is happening!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You're a sub. Your position  has never been permanent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Dennis! You're not helping! (softly, to Roberta) Come into my office, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave Dennis standing there, looking as if he's had face slapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's gotta be a way to fight this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight it with what? I don't have any  other extra programs to give them  instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. So after ten years, after  fourteen hundred children have learned  to play the violin, this is just an  "extra program."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I don't feel that way and  you know damn well I've been standing  by you all these years! You think I  haven't noticed what you've done for  these kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then do something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to her phone) I've been on this phone for the past  three days trying to "do something" --  the District office can't even stand  the sound of my voice. Believe me,  there are some people around here  I'd much rather get rid of. But as  far as the Board's concerned, violin  classes are not a priority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's fury starts to give way to grief. She looks ter wounded. Janet looks at her helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the power here, Roberta.  I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, and Roberta exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's dazed and in pain as she walks through the crow of children, oblivious to kids calling her name and wavin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Lexi enter the darkened house, chatting as Nick  wheels in the bike and Lexi bounces a basketball. They tu on a light to reveal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sitting at the kitchen table with a  glass of wine, her face ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta, Nick and Lexi walk Allegra in their neighborhood Roberta looks worn out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a good teacher. I've worked so  hard to give these kids something to  be proud of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi moves to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Mom. I can't believe  they did this to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like when my father got killed.  For twenty years, he followed every  safety rule the factory had, and  then someone else flips the wrong  switch... (she chokes up) It's not fair. You do everything  right and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the wrong analogy. You couldn't  do anything about Grandpa's death.  It was irreversible. This isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that to the Board of Education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. Why did  you risk your life for a bicycle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta and Lexi look at Nick, baffled as to the relevanc of the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not risk my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you did! That building?  Threatening Henry? And for what --  two hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When someone steals something that  belongs to my kids, I'm not gonna  sit back and let that happen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as she realizes what she's just said. The boys loo at her and the three of them stop walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys -- you need to think about this.  If I try to fight this -- with no  salary coming in -- I could lose the  house, screw up your college plans...  It would be a lot safer to just go  out tomorrow and get a job in a  private school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but is that where you really  want to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta frantically searches through her purse, then cros to a hall closet and quickly checks the pockets of her co and jackets. She feels inside a jacket pocket, then finds it: DOROTHEA BUSINESS CARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW DAN PAXTON as he walks down the hall towards his o and sees a strange silver object on the floor in front of his office door. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- A foil-covered plate with a note on top: DO YOU KNOW A

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Dan lifts up the foil to reveal a large piece of LASAGNA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEVENTY-FIVE KIDS play "We Shall Overcome" and it's incre moving. Nick's on cello, Lexi plays piano. ROBERTA proudl leads the children. At the side of the stage, we see DORO photographing the concert. THE CAMERA PANS THE AUDIENCE o teary-eyed parents, many of them with CAM CORDERS. We FIN Ramon's family. Manuelo is riverted by his son's playing, and he starts to cry. Concepcion knows this without looki She takes his hand. ANGLE - JANET stands along the side and her eyes start to fill with tears. She tries to stay composed, then discree exits the auditorium. The song ends and the audience APPLAUDS, rising from thei seats, including ASSUNTA (now 65), next to ISABEL and DAN Someone remains seated: a REPORTER (40's), sitting beside Dan and taking notes. The STUDENTS bow, then point to Roberta who bows and take the stage. She gestures for people to sit. A beginner stu brings her flowers. Roberta kisses her, then approaches t mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the audience) The beautiful concert that you just  heard could be the last concert of  the East Harlem Violin Program. The  Board of Education and the District  Superintendent don't think that music  is important for our children. But  they're wrong -- and they're in for  a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parents stand and applaud. We see the REPORTER writin quickly. Dorothea snaps more pictures. Roberta extends an arm towards the kids, directing the applause at them. Ram gives her a thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERTA is vacuuming the living room while Assunta dusts. Extra chairs are set up in the living room in preparation for a meeting. The doorbell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW ASSUNTA to the DOOR. She opens it, revealing JANET who's carrying two bags of groceries. Assunta's demeanor  instantly cools when she sees her. In the b.g. Roberta se Janet and turns off the vacuum cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Assunta. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be a lot better if my daughter  had a job next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Assunta) I would too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet briskly walks into THE LIVING ROOM, puts the grocer bags down on a table, and begins to take things out of th Roberta watches her, mystified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roberta) Sorry I'm early, but I figured we'd  need time to set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta watches Janet for a beat, then addresses Assunta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, why don't you take Allegra out  for a walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assunta hesitates for a beat, then gets the dog and exits Janet continues unpacking the bags as if there's nothing  unusual about her being there. Cheeses, crackers, bread,  salads, fruit, paper plates, napkins, etc. She sees Rober confused expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are having a meeting here tonight,  right? Parents and teachers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it from me. If you want to get  parents to help you with something,  you have to feed them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up two wedges of cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a cutting board for these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta crosses into the kitchen and returns with a cutti board and a knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she continues to  unpack) And if you think parents are bad,  teachers are even worse, no offense.  If you don't feed them, you never  get anything extra out of them. That's  why I got this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls out an Entenmann's blackout cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entenmann's gets them every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta continues to stare in amazement at Janet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Don't tell me you expected me  to bring something homemade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she takes the  cake from her) Well, no... I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Because take it from me -- my  own family begs me to stay out of  the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I didn't expect was for you to  be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? We've gotta figure out a  way to fight this. (as she arranges  crackers on a plate) After ten years, Roberta, I can't  imagine walking through those hallways  and not hearing that off-key,  screechy, scratchy, nails-on-the- blackboard violin music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta smiles. Janet holds up a baguette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? Cut it into slices  now, or leave it whole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's cut it now. It'll be less messy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet hands her the bread. A beat as the two women exchan a private smile, then return to their respective tasks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a crowd of PARENTS assembled in Roberta's front r talking at once, yelling out ideas, including CONCEPCION, BEVERLY WILSON (Shandra's mom), MR. ADAMS (Black) and MRS ADAMS (Puerto Rican), the parents of James (from Roberta' first year) and Simon. DOROTHEA, JANET, ISABEL are also t ASSUNTA is keeping tabs on the refreshments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they realize how much this  program helps the kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon's our third child to study  with Roberta. James is pre-med,  April's valedictorian -- now that  says something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should inundate the Board  and the District with letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wasting your time. The Board  and the District are not gonna pay  for this program, no matter how many  letters they get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappointed grumblings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we raise the money ourselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see how they'd object to  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as people take this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well once that newspaper article  comes out, that should help bring in  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but what if it doesn't? For  all we know, it's gonna be buried on  the back page. Besides, who says  anyone's gonna give a damn about our  kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roberta) What if you do a benefit concert? We  can raise a batch of money from ticket  sales, and then the concert itself  could be great publicity. There's  word of mouth... you could get  reviewed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better be a good concert!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people laugh but we see the anxiety on Roberta's fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to offer something more than  me and the kids. (to Dorothea) Do you think maybe your husband would  perform with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slyly) I'm sure I could persuade him with a  little pillow talk. And maybe he can  get another violinist too -- Itzhak  Perlman, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gets people's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could rent a place like the 92nd  Street Y -- it's perfect for this.  It seats about nine hundred people  and if we charge between fifty and a  hundred a ticket --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roberta) We could probably raise enough to  reinstate your program for a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half to herself) It better be a good concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS and Roberta crosses to get it. DAN ent holding copies of the NY POST, the DAILY NEWS, and a coup of other papers. Each paper has been opened to a specific page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta grabs the top one -- the POST -- opened to page 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The page has a photo of Roberta at the Spring Concert, an large article headlined A VIOLIN TEACHER FIGHTS BACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of chaos as a TELEVISION NEWS CREW sets up. Roberta  tries futilely to get the beginners to pay attention to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids, listen to me -- it's really  important that you don't look at the  camera and you try to act as natural  as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis storms in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who authorized this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Janet's not here today and I  want these people out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids quiet down and watch them argue. A CAMERA GUY st shooting the argument and Dennis sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn that off, you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this? We're not  bothering anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're disrupting school and I want  them out of here -- now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still don't get it, do you? I  don't care if you hate me, Dennis --  that's your business. But think about  the students for once. Every time  you interfere, you're not hurting me --  you're hurting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to the kids. They're silent, waiting to see if Roberta got through to him. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get these people out of here or I'm  calling the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go right ahead, call them. That'll  look real good on the eleven o'clock  news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat and he exits. Roberta takes a deep breath, then tu back to the kids who are watching her, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hear no sirens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TV is the news segment: ROBERTA speaks to an unsee interviewer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from a blue collar family, and  if it weren't for the lessons I got  in public school, I never would have  learned the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It CUTS TO Roberta's beginners speaking to the interviewe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does it make you feel to lose  your violin program?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes us sad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, like we're never gonna have no  more violin lessons --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's bad because... because we  love violin class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDER - REVEAL Roberta, Lexi and Nick watching the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I've gotten offers from two  private schools, but this is where I  want to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arnold, these kids need help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDER - REVEAL a comfortable Upper East Side apartment an DOROTHEA watching T.V. while ARNOLD practices violin. The FRAMED PHOTOGRAPHY on the walls, signed by Dorothea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't we send them a donation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They need something bigger. And you  can't just write a check -- you have  to get involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Involved how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look on her face tells him it's more than he bargaine for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. Arnold Steinhardt speaks on the phone. His Roladex is  open to the name ITZHAK PERLMAN. In the b.g., Dorothea te waits to hear if Itzhak Perlman will say yes. 2. Parents, Roberta, Nick and Lexi hang "FIDDLEFEST CONCE posters around their neighborhood, announcing a concert a THE 92ND STREET Y with ARNOLD STEINHARDT, ITZHAK PERLMAN STUDENTS FROM THE EAST HARLEM VIOLIN PROGRAM. 3. Parents -- including Beverly Wilson, Concepcion, Mr. A and Carlos' mom and dad -- stuff envelopes with INVITATIO to "FIDDLEFEST" and accompanying LETTERS and TICKET ORDER FORMS. Roberta and Dorothea open envelopes with filled-ou TICKET ORDER FORMS and CHECKS. They stack the checks in a pile, address return envelopes and place FIDDLEFEST TICKE inside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-three excited kids from Roberta's different classe chat, tune their violins, rosin their bows. The students  include Carlos, Stephanie, Amanda, Kenny, Rachel, Simon,  Ramon, Vanessa, and Shandra. Roberta enters the room, ful of energy, and addresses them as she heads to the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen up, everyone! Quiet down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students give her their attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are my very best beginner and  advanced violin students and I've  chosen you to play in Fiddlefest  because I trust that you can handle  the pressure. It's gonna be a lot of  work -- a lot. Right now, we've sold  some tickets, but I'm not gonna be  back here in the fall if the audience  storms out of their seats, demanding  a refund!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods to Rachel who starts handing out sheets of music

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel's gonna be my lieutenant and  I expect you to listen to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon looks through his music sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bach's "Minuet One"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are gonna be paying good money  for this concert -- we're not just  gonna play "Twinkle." (handing out papers) I'm passing out a contract that you  and your parents need to sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids read the contracts. Carlos' eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every Saturday and Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus night time rehearsals during  the week. There's only six weeks  till the concert, so classes in school  won't be enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids look sobered by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to think of it, we'll probably  also need to meet before school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of grumbling: "Say what?" "No way!" "Before school?" I'ma be sleepwalking!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've heard of Navy Seal Training?  Well, this is gonna be Roberta String  Training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE - Two young men and two young women walk in carrying violins. We realize from the scar that one is NA (20), now a strikingly handsome man, over six feet tall.  With him is DE SEAN (19), a short guy with dreadlocks, lo more like a rapper than a violinist. GUADALUPE (19), walk with a cane, is now a beautiful young woman, her long bra pinned up. The fourth is a reserved Puerto Rican woman (2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god! Naeem! De Sean! (hugs them) Guadalupe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs her, then looks closely at the other woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
