dialogues.text: Lucy? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman snaps her fingers and smiles. Roberta laughs an embraces her, then turns to the students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids, these are four of my very first  violin students and I've asked them  to play in the concert with us. (to the alumni) I was just telling them how hard  they're gonna have to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to class) Take it from me -- this lady don't  lie. Y'all are gonna work your butts  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramon's father carefully reads the violin contract while  Ramon and Concepcion anxiously watch. He stops to look up word in the English-Spanish dictionary beside him. Ramon his mom are squirming. Manuelo nods as he finishes readin then SIGNS the contract. Ramon breaks into a smile, throw his little arms around his Papa and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School's letting out; Carlos' sister exits, carrying Carl violin. A few beats later, Carlos quickly exits, checking his watch. He sees his LOS LEONES teammates standing in a group, and tries to bypass them without being noticed, bu they spot him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Carlos! Where ya goin'? We got a  game, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, but... I can't make  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a date with the violin  teacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dashes off, a barrage of Spanish and English curses be him, and crosses to his sister, waiting for him DOWN THE  STREET. He takes the violin from her and carries it himse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fiddlefest kids, including Carlos, Vanessa, Shandra,  Ramon, Stephanie, Amanda, Kenny, Simon, Thomas, De Sean a Guadalupe practice Bach's "Minuet One," Roberta leading t and giving direction. They're playing badly. Rachel plays as well, but walks around the room making  corrections. It's early morning, and the kids look half- asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frog! Frog! I need more accents on  the down beat! More bow! More!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They play a few more bars and still sound pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop! (they do so) You sound horrible! Isn't anyone  practicing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we practice? We're rehearsing  all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kids laugh, including Stephanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stephanie) You think this is funny, Stephanie? (to all of them) You think the four hundred people  who've bought tickets so far will  think it's funny too? You think Itzhak  Perlman will think it's funny that  he's donating his time and you're  all gonna stink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa yawns and Roberta sees her. Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I boring you, Vanessa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's 7:30 in the morning. I'm  just tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no time to be tired. (to all, getting her  violin in position) Let's try it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea opens the door for Roberta who just charges in,  agitated, without even saying hello. We sense that Doroth too, is troubled by something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have been crazy to agree to  this. They're never gonna be ready.  And you should hear the Bach Double!  A disaster. So the good news is  tickets are selling like hot cakes,  but the bad news is that the kids  sound like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more bad news... We've lost  the Y.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at her, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had a flood -- a water heater  burst... The concert hall was damaged  and they've cancelled all events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Until further notice."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't happen! We've sold tickets!  We've done publicity! The concert's  in three weeks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been on the phone all morning  calling other theaters. Nothing's  available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both sink into the couch, completely undone by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fiddlefest kids are crammed into Roberta's house,  (including De Sean, Guadalupe, Ramon, Vanessa, Shandra,  Carlos, Thomas, Stephanie, Amanda, Kenny, and Simon),  rehearsing "Orange Blossom Special." They play badly. Rac helps Roberta correct students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Someone's playing the wrong  notes! And you shouldn't need your  music anymore! Except for the Bach  Double, everything has to be memorized  by next rehearsal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids look at each other, daunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you sound like you're  sleepwalking. Your heart's not even  in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe 'cause we don't have a place  for the concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at her, and then notices the despondent loo on many of the kids' faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're right. This might all  be for nothing. So we can either  keep on rehearsing in case we find a  place -- or we can just... give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I hearing right? Did you use the  words "give up"? (to the students) Let's take a vote. How many of you  want to give up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one raises a hand. Roberta takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? You taught us well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early morning. Lexi cooks breakfast while Nick and  Roberta look at scribbled-on, marked-up lists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about in the Bronx?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing. (beat) Why don't you just do it in one of  the schools? It'll be a lot smaller  but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't make enough money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about postponing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Itzhak and Arnold are booked all  summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look depressed. Lexi places an equally depressin looking stack of pancakes on the table. There's a BANGING the door, startling everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Dorothea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick opens the door and Dorothea rushes in, out of breath talking a mile a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have good news -- really good news.  Arnold got a call from his friend  Wally Scheur who heard about us losing  the Y and wanted to see how he could  help -- and then Wally had this  brilliant idea and called his friend  Isaac Stern and it's all arranged!  We have a new place for Fiddlefest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothea grins from ear to ear, Nick and Lexi whoop and  holler, and all wait for Roberta to jump up and down for but she looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicked) Carnegie Hall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE CEILING OF CARNEGIE HALL, revolving slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands on the empty stage, gazing at the ceiling as s slowly turns around. She's holding her violin case. She l at the UPPER BALCONIES -- THE LOWER BALCONIES -- THE ORCH SEATS. Her footsteps echo as she walks towards the front the stage, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: We can see her imagining the audience on the night of the concert. She can't believe her eyes. A beat, and she look around to make sure she's alone. She takes out her violin takes a deep breath as she looks out towards her "audienc then starts to play the second violin part of the Bach Do Concerto. Suddenly, there's the SOUND of a stage door ope Roberta stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible sound in this room, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta turns to see ISAAC STERN approaching her. She's  completely flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god -- Isaac Stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for helping us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out at the  hall) Would you believe in 1960, they tried  to tear this place down? They wanted  to replace it with a bright red  skyscraper -- we called it "the red  terror."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had to fight like hell, but with  a lot of help, we saved Carnegie  Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta takes this in, relating it to her own struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's all right with you, I'd like  to play in your concert. Maybe bring  a couple of friends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course! That would be great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac nods, then touches her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta pours nervous energy into her cappuccino, adding  cinnamon, chocolate, and sugar, stirring loudly. Dan sits across from her, observing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't see how I'm gonna do  this. It's huge. It's gigantic! It's  Carnegie Hall! And listen to this:  now Isaac Stern wants to play with  us -- Diane Monroe, Michael Tree --  there's other people calling --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fantastic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic? I'll never get the kids  up to speed in time, I'll never get  myself up to speed. I'm gonna be  playing side by side with the world's  greatest violinists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And "the world's greatest violinists"  are playing side by side with you  because they want to help you win  this fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers her a forkful of some decadent-looking chocolat cake, but she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but... you don't understand.  Maybe there's a good reason why I  never made it as a violinist -- maybe  I just can't cut it. I keep blaming  it on not having enough early  training, but if I were talented, if  I had a gift --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you do have a gift. You're gonna  put thirty East Harlem kids on stage  at Carnegie Hall not because they're  prodigies, but because you got them  to stick with something that's hard  as hell and to strive for excellence --  which, by the way, I certainly wasn't  striving for when I was their age.  Not to mention the other ten years'  worth of students whose lives were  changed because of you. That's your  talent, Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes this in, looks at him gratefully and puts her h over his. He strokes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (beat) And by the way, I happen to think  you're a pretty good violinist too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've barely heard me play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard enough to know you're  gonna do just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at him with trepidation. Dan takes another  forkful of his cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, no one's gonna be paying  attention to your playing anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta laughs. Dan smiles, glad he got her to lighten up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fiddlefest kids (including Ramon, Shandra, Vanessa, D Sean, Naeem, Guadalupe, Lucy, Simon, Stephanie, Amanda an Kenny -- but RACHEL is absent) stand outside the locked s gate, waiting for Roberta. Some of the kids have their vi out of the cases, tuning them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teacher's late. I think she should  be dropped, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don't think we should let  her play in Fiddlefest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few kids start playing "CAN-CAN." It catches on, and mo of them join in. PASSERSBY stop to listen, and some drop  change into the open cases. RAMON and a couple of other k grin at this. CARLOS steps in front of the kids as he plays, and begins uncanny imitation of Roberta:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More bow! To the frog! You sound  terrible! I can't believe how terrible  you sound!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids crack up, but a few spot ROBERTA heading quickly the street. Carlos is oblivious to this -- and no one sig him that Roberta's watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna make everyone in Carnegie  Hall sick to their stomachs! That's  right, they're gonna pay a thousand  dollars a ticket and you're gonna  make them throw up on their gowns  and tuxedos!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos senses a presence and turns to see Roberta. A tens beat as he awaits her reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in all seriousness) If you're gonna imitate me, do it  right. (corrects his posture) Shoulders back. Violin higher. Check  your feet. There. (beat) G'head, Carlos. Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's O.K. You can take it from  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta nods, and addresses the kids as she unlocks the g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, by the way. You do sound  terrible, and you are gonna make  everyone in Carnegie Hall sick to  their stomachs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids start filing in. Rachel comes up the street and  catches up to Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta sees how distressed Rachel looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to kids) I'll be right in. Start on Minuet  One. (to Rachel) What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're moving away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Where are you moving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking downward) It's a secret... My father... he's  been hurting my mom... We have to  leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Has he been hurting you too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel shakes her head no, then starts to cry a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about Julliard... and the  concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Roberta her violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it. Take it with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I don't want to play anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! You can't give up violin,  Rachel -- it's a part of you. A very  important part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel looks anguished. Roberta moves closer and touches arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please honey. Just take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta looks at her, pained, then hugs her. Rachel quick kisses Roberta goodbye and exits. Roberta watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta leads De Sean, Naeem, Guadalupe, Lucy, Stephanie, Thomas, Carlos, Erica and Nicholas in the Bach Double  Concerto. The other kids watch. Roberta's on the edge of  hysteria. She signals the players to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no! Accent the up bow after  the slurred notes and then it'll get  you off of those slurred notes! You  Double Concerto kids need to be  working harder! This is the grand  finale of the concert! You're each  gonna be sharing a music stand with  one of the world's greatest  violinists!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids say "the world's greatest violinists" along with her -- they've obviously been hearing this a lot. Roberta glares at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should forget the Bach  Double. (to the other kids) And you guys are never gonna get  Minuet One. I think we should drop  that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! We can do it, Roberta!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll get the Bach Double. We  will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna be O.K., Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vulnerable) You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the kids nod. A few beats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K... (not believing it) It's gonna be O.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to take a look at her music, and the kids exc looks that say, "Oh shit. What did we just promise?"

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: 1. Carlos practices violin against the fence around River East School. In the b. g., his buddies make fun of him. 2. Shandra practices in a school stairwell, ignoring a bo who pulls one of her braids as he passes by. 3. Stephanie practices at a bus stop, her eyes closed, th looks up and realizes she's just missed her bus. 4. Ramon practices in his living room, his father watchin attentively, then helping him lift the violin higher. 5. Vanessa practices in a crowded school hallway, frustra as kids keep bumping into her. 6. Roberta, in her nightgown, practices in front of her  refrigerator in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pandemonium. Nick and Lexi, both in tuxes, are doing seve tasks at once while Roberta, in a simple black velvet dre and stockinged feet, tries to put on her makeup but keeps poking her head out of the bathroom, giving orders. Alleg BARKS outside the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick -- did you feed Allegra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fixing Lexi's tie) Yes, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi, can you make sure the charts  are still in my bag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already checked, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check again, please. And look for my  repair kit too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ASSUNTA descends the staircase, dressed in a formal dress She holds a small jewelry box and heads for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, which earrings you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta sticks her head out and picks the earrings. Assun enters the small bathroom to work on her own makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick? Get two more violins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've already got two -- how many  emergencies can there be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get three more. And make sure a couple  of them are half-size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick rolls his eyes and runs upstairs while Lexi organize things by the door: Nick's cello, Roberta's papers, extra violins. Roberta rushes out of the bathroom, adjusting th earrings. She starts compulsively straightening the house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lexi -- can you call about the car  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, they're not gonna forget to  send a car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick comes running down the stairs with the violins and s in disbelief at Roberta fluffing a couch pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just straightening a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane, you know that? (grabs the pillow) Finish getting dressed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the pillow onto the couch. Roberta heads upstai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE MIRROR - Carlos adjusts his tuxedo. We see the  reflection of his baseball bat, glove and trophies in the room behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe's mom pins up her braid, then steps back to loo at her daughter, radiant in a floral gown. Her mom starts cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly puts rhinestone-studded barrettes in Shandra's ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON RAMON - He's in a sharp black suit and looks very dapp WIDER - Manuelo and Concepcion stand back to admire him,  then Manuelo straightens Ramon's tie, brimming with pride over his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Assunta look towards the stairs. Roberta comes  running down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns around, revealing a RIP on the back of the dres next to the zipper. The DOORBELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be time! Is it time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sew it in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta, Assunta and the boys step outside, amazed to see STRETCH LIMOUSINE double-parked in front, a CHAUFFEUR wai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? I told you they'd send a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta's open-mouthed. She leads her entourage towards t limo. THE NEIGHBORS come out of their houses to watch. So lean out windows, gawking. Ad libs... "Who's that?" "It's the Violin Lady!" LAWRENCE, dressed in a tux, gives Lexi high sign. The chauffeur helps Roberta and Assunta into the limo whi Nick and Lexi start to load the instruments into the trun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta sits down beside Assunta and turns around so Assu can mend the tear in her dress. Assunta partially unzips dress and starts stitching it from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. You rip -- I  sew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just for that. (beat) Thank you for getting me out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assunta stitches, remembering, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't thank me -- thank Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that jerk hadn't of left you,  none of this would've happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta contemplates this. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her last stitch finished, Assunta rips the needle from th thread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids and their parents are practically boiling over w excitement. Last minute kisses, violin tunings, and cloth adjustments take place throughout the room. The boys are in suits or tuxes, the girls in velvet or  flowered dresses, some with bows in their hair, some with their hair up in buns. Roberta tries to take a head count Dorothea confers with a stage manager, Assunta fixes a bo tie, and Janet helps one girl with her hair, stopping in middle to button the back of another girl's dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Vanessa? Has anyone seen  Vanessa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet looks at her, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - Roberta sees MRS. ADISA enter the room with Naeem The two women walk towards each other and embrace. As the start to chat, Roberta suddenly sees someone and excuses  herself: BRIAN is walking towards her, wearing a tux. The smile at each other, but Roberta's clearly a bit shaken t see him. They're not quite sure how to greet each other - he takes her hand, and then kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd get here sooner or later.  I'm glad I'm here to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guadalupe shyly approaches Itzhak Perlman, her mother beh her, silently encouraging her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Perlman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extends a hand) I'm Guadalupe. I've wanted to meet  you for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at her and they shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you, Guadalupe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Guadalupe introduces him to her mother, CARLOS approac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You nervous, Mr. Perlman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Us kids are gonna be great -- I don't  know about you guys. How much did  you practice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Itzhak Perlman laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta talks to Janet with a worried expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called Vanessa's father and  mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer at either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Carnegie Hall staff person in a suit enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half hour call! It's now half hour  call! So pace yourself accordingly.  Don't get more than thirty minutes  worth of nervous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room electrifies with nerves.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: rushes into the room with her father. She's out of breath her stocking has a big run in it, and she's in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stole the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. (calling) Nick, Lexi --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys rush over to the extra violins and look to find right size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) And then when we were getting a taxi,  I fell down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta comforts her and Janet moves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon honey -- let's get you cleaned  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - DAN enters with a bouquet of long-stemmed red ros He's in a tux and looks very handsome. He crosses to Robe hands her the flowers, and they hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're glowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is filling to capacity as people take their seat the room buzzing with voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CARNEGIE HALL staff person enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE MINUTE CALL. WE NOW HAVE FIVE  MINUTES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tension in the room shoots sky high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet stands onstage and addresses the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I became the principal of Central  Park East Elementary, I envisioned a  school where children could fulfill  their highest potential, despite the  challenges of poverty and racism.  Ten years ago, Roberta Guaspari walked  into my office because she needed a  job, and because she had a vision  that any child could learn the violin.  We put our dreams together and created  the East Harlem Violin Program which  has helped more than a thousand  students expand their vision of what's  possible in their lives. When a  program like this is cut, our  children's future is compromised. I  want to thank you for your support.  Enjoy the concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. we hear the audience APPLAUDING Janet. Robert holds up her hands to quiet down the anxious students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone -- attention please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They become quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you all to take a second just  to breathe, O.K.? Deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like you all to play with  your heart, all right? Play like I  know you can play. You'll be  wonderful. Watch me, don't look out  in the audience -- you don't need to  be afraid. It's gonna be really  wonderful. So play -- play from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pats her heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids head out towards the stage, the APPLAUSE getting louder as they get closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE SHOT of the children on stage, in their positions.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE STAGE
dialogues.text: Some of the kids look awestruck by the audience; one subt waves hi to her family. Roberta walks out to APPLAUSE. Sh bows to the audience, turns to the kids, signals them wit slight nod and the BACH MINUET ONE begins. We've heard it all phases, and now it is flawless. PAN the STUDENTS watching her: VANESSA, wearing a corsage SIMON in his red bow tie; SHANDRA in black velvet with pe NAEEM standing proud and tall, DE SEAN in dreadlocks and tux; RAMON playing from his heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac Stern, Itzhak Perlman, Michael Tree, Arnold Steinha Diane Monroe, Karen Briggs and Mark O'Connor wait back st chatting and listening to the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students finish MINUET ONE. There's an exquisite mome of silence, then APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Country fiddler MARK O'CONNOR plays ORANGE BLOSSOM SPECIA with the kids. He improvises, surprising them as his viol makes the sound of a TRAIN moving through a tunnel. RAMON smiles, awed by this -- but he remains calm and  professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the guest violinists head for the stage, we hear their names over a mike, mixed with APPLAUSE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac Stern, Itzhak Perlman, Arnold  Steinhardt, Diane Monroe, Michael  Tree, Mark O'Connor and Karen Briggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE SHOT of the six guest violinists on stage for the G Finale, each one sharing a music stand with a student. Ro nods, and they begin THE BACH DOUBLE CONCERTO. She turns face the audience as she joins them. MOVE IN AND PAN the performers and students: NAAEM shares stand with ARNOLD STEINHARDT; ISAAC STERN stands and play with GUADALUPE, sitting beside him; ITZHAK PERLMAN sits a plays next to CARLOS, standing beside him; MICHAEL TREE p beside DE SEAN; DIANE MONROE plays beside LUCY; KAREN BRI plays beside THOMAS, and MARK O'CONNOR plays beside STEPH NICK plays cello; LEXI plays the piano behind them; and,  playing with her own solo music stand, ROBERTA. Their expressions are serious and passionate, broken by  occasional smiles lighting on faces: Isaac Stern... Lucy. Carlos... Itzhak Perlman... Diane Monroe... De Sean. The song finishes and the APPLAUSE begins. The OTHER  FIDDLEFEST PLAYERS come out from back stage, RAMON in fro and join the rest. More applause. The CAMERA PULLS BACK T INCLUDE the audience facing the stage, then REVERSES to s the audience standing in the orchestra and balconies. We see the students' PARENTS; JANET, ISABEL and their  families; ASSUNTA, LAWRENCE and DOROTHEA; DAN; CONCEPCION MANUELO and their sons; BRIAN; and DENNIS -- even he can' stop himself from applauding. BACK AGAIN to the stage where the students and guest  violinists bow... and MOVE IN CLOSER on ROBERTA in her mo of triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta addresses the audience. Her voice is strong but s around the edges; she is a woman in a state of grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all here tonight because we  have a bigger mission: to take the  magical spirit of tonight's concert  with us out into the world, and to  fight for music and art to be a part  of every child's education. Thank  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The APPLAUSE is DEAFENING, then slowly diminishes as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta addresses ten first-graders sitting in a circle o the floor. She points to the horsehair on her bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this? What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The frog hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta and the kids laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever see a frog with hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's horsehair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. (to the boy) But you're right, there is a frog.  Can you show me where it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One girl raises her hand with urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh! I know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh -- let him answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy points to the frog of the bow and Roberta smiles. And as she continues her lesson, her voice recedes and we

dialogues.speaker: CRAWL
dialogues.text: Roberta Guaspari lives in East Harlem with her daughter S whom she adopted from El Salvador. Nick is a professional cellist in a graduate music program, and Alexi has been  accepted to medical school. Roberta teaches violin to approximately 150 students a ye in three East Harlem elementary schools. The East Harlem  Violin Program, however, is still not funded by the New Y City Board of Education. The money raised from Fiddlefest supported Roberta's viol program for three years. Roberta and Opus 118 continue th fundraising efforts to keep the program alive.
